text:
100 Broad Street, west side, at the intersection of Bridge and Broad Streets. Also shown is Bridge Street, north side, west from Broad, to, but not including Whitehall Street. Building shown is occupied by the Bush Terminal Buildings Co.

About 1920.

98-96 Broad Street, west side, from, but not including, Bridge Street, to and including Stone Street. The buildings in the foreground will soon be replaced by the 24-story Stone & Webster Building. No. 88, at the N.W. corner of Stone Street, has just been demolished, and will be replaced by a three-story building.

June 20, 1929.

P. L. Sperr.

(1)

98-92 Broad Street, at, adjoining, and north of the N.W. corner of Bridge Street. In the background is the tower of the Produce Exchange.

June 20, 1929.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)

The same, also showing the Bush Terminal Company at the left. The buildings shown in No. 1 have been demolished and work has begun on the 24-story Stone & Webster Building, which will occupy the block from Bridge to Stone Streets. At the right, the 36-story Maritime Exchange Building is about half finished.

October 3, 1930.

P. L. Sperr.

(1)

98-92 Broad Street, at, adjoining, and north of the N.W. corner of Bridge Street. In the background is the tower of the Produce Exchange.

June 20, 1929.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)

The same, also showing the Bush Terminal Company at the left. The buildings shown in No. 1 have been demolished and work has begun on the 24-story Stone & Webster Building, which will occupy the block from Bridge to Stone Streets. At the right, the 36-story Maritime Exchange Building is about half finished.

October 3, 1930.

P. L. Sperr.

98-68 Broad Street, west side, from Bridge to Beaver Streets, inclusive, also showing 11-21 Stone Street, west of, adjoining, and at the N.W. corner of Broad Street. The Stone & Webster Building will rise on the clearing in the foreground. The three-story building on the N.W. corner of Stone Street has replaced a five-story building. The next four buildings, the last of which is the Maritime Exchange, will be demolished for the Maritime Exchange Building.

September 20, 1929.

P. L. Sperr.
